body:
can you confirm you have no labels in the top left corner your images when you run "check_labels" on your dataset ...? 

also, GPU: RTX 3090 does NOT support Tensorflow 1! #944 #1119 will send you to use our TF2 code base, which is currently on the `main` branch of deeplabcutcore

Doesn't #1017 solve that? I ran the following code:

```
pip install git+https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut-core.git@tf2.2alpha
pip install tf_slim
```
I can confirm I have no labels in the top left corner under .../labeled-data/_videofile__labeled. They are all correctly placed.

^^ also note that now one can also just use `pip install git+https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut-core.git` or (in a few mins, `pip install deeplabcutcore` ðŸ‘¯â€â™€ï¸ 

@ejdrup -- it must be you have TF1.x installed; we confirm this happens with TF 1, but NOT TF2!

rename.from: All predictions place in top left-hand corner
rename.to: All predictions place in top left-hand corner [ RTX 3*** does NOT work with TensorFlow 1.x! == odd errors! Please use deeplabcutcore ]

body: Cool. Would I need a fresh install of DLC-GPU environ, or can I just pip in the old environment?

in the same env you can run `pip uninstall tensorflow` then `pip install tensorflow==2.4` and `pip install deeplabcutcore`

(or also of course you can just make a new one)

This is brand new setup, and we already have way too many cross-dependencies trying to load different cudnn and cuda versions, so we're just doing a fresh install. Which Ubuntu flavor do you guys use? It's primarily going to be a tracking workstations anyway, so trying to mimic your environment as much as possible.

issue.title: DeepLabCut-core unable to engage RTX 3090

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
OS: Ubuntu 20.10 (Pop!_OS)
DeepLabCut Version: DeepLabCut-core
CUDA: 11.0
cudnn: 8.0.4
Tensorflow 2.4
GPU: RTX 3090

This is regarding deeplabcut-core, but the documentation linked this way, so thought best to post the issue here.

My DLC seems to be unable to engage my RTX 3090 graphics card. I've installed the DLC-GPU environment and run the following commands from #1142 :

```
pip uninstall tensorflow
pip install tensorflow==2.4
pip install deeplabcutcore
```

I've reused the old labels, and remade the training set with DLC-core, but when I start training it remains stuck at "starting training..." for at least 3 hours (longest test).

I can successfully import tensorflow and get the following when running:
`
tf.test.gpu_device_name()
`

The testscript.py for DLC-core can start training, but does so at a very slow rate, and does not seem engage the GPU either. Running nvidia-smi no other major tasks are engaged on the GPU.

issue.title: poor tracking results with 3080 GPU

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
Dear deeplabcut team,

First of all thank you for making this great program!  I am encountering some difficulties getting accurate tracking of the shape of a mouse's eyelid. I would like to get some help here. 

My DLC environment: OS: Windows 10. GPU: NVIDIA Geforce RTX 3080   Cuda: 10.0 . & DLC-GPU environment file. Deeplabcut Version: 2.1.10.4

I extracted and hand-labeled 90 frames using kmeans method. Then I created the trainingset using RESNET-50 (didn't change other parameters in pose yaml config file). I can normally run all the steps in the program. However, the training results are very poor. The train and test errors are over 200. And based on the inference coordinates, all the 6 markers are located on the corner of the image, which is far- far away from my hand-labeled coordinates.

Description of my video: mice are head-fixed so the lighting and position of all the labels are pretty similar across frames. I thought tracking this type of videos should be relatively  easy compared to a freely moving animal. But the results seem to be far from accurate. I am thinking that I'm missing some important step, but I couldn't figure it out. 

I have attached an example image of the video, the training results summary, hand-labeled coordinates, result coordinates, plus the 2 config files down below. Please let me know if other info is needed. Thank you again!!

![manually labeled video](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18105990/120143517-d42f4680-c212-11eb-9ad0-a92b7ee0f01b.PNG)
![combined evaluation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18105990/120143522-d7c2cd80-c212-11eb-862a-77e0aab9dec4.PNG)
![labeled coordinates](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18105990/120143533-dabdbe00-c212-11eb-91f3-54b2c3a56a11.PNG)
![results coordinate](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18105990/120143543-dd201800-c212-11eb-83b2-feeb088b27af.PNG)

[configfile.txt](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/6567928/configfile.txt)
[pose_cfgfile.txt](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/files/6567929/pose_cfgfile.txt)

body:
NOTE: we now support 3090 and TensorFlow 2! Please install a new conda file, you can direct download from deeplabcut.org - this comes with 2.2rc3 installed inside the conda, the latest tensorflow, and works with the latest CUDA.

see the blog: http://blog.deeplabcut.org/ for the new code base highlights
